history.content:
Source: have taken both, was a 61C TA for a bit basically just because of that fact

There have been a few answers in this Piazza that have touched on this: @10496, @10078, @9788, @8841, @9517,  @9775, @9648. Apparently I need to get a life. 

To answer your question, I guess it depends on your perspective. I took 105, 140, and 151 before 152, so I didn't find the one or two references to DRAM operation in 152 to be all that intimidating (and it really doesn't go much farther than that in terms of "circuits"), but the highly-qualified TAs in 152 had the opposite, likely more prevalent perspective that this material kind of comes out of left field for students without previous exposure to circuits. For the most part, though, 152 is very much a computer science course where programming / scripting nous is far, far more valuable than understanding how charge-sharing allows DRAM to function. If you mastered 61C, you should be perfectly well-prepared for 152.

152 is an incredibly unique course that is reserved for graduate students at just about all other universities and almost makes me want to forgive Berkeley for many, many other poor educational experiences. It was definitely really cool to learn how real CPUs and GPUs work, and the labs often draw on resources that are derived directly from recent research done at Cal. Full disclosure: 152 is conceptually rather tough and has the roughest curve of any class I have ever taken or likely will ever take, since basically everyone in the class is / could be a 61C TA. 

151 is a digital circuits class, with an additional focus on microarchitecture (the "nuts and bolts" of a processor). It has a much higher workload, primarily because of the lab and project, but conceptually isn't all too tough. Both labs offer really valuable exposure to "real-world" design, but I'd recommend the ASIC lab if you take this course next semester, since it doesn't require hands-on interaction (I took the FPGA version of the lab, which requires you to run your design on a real FPGA). 61C and the part of 16B about logic networks are good enough preparation for 151. One thing I really liked about 151 is that the course progression basically matched the conceptual content covered in a series of interviews I did with Nvidia while I was taking it. That's proof enough that 151 is the go-to course for an aspiring hardware engineer; with 152 on top of that, I'd say that there's no reason why you couldn't be hired as a computer architect at any of Intel, Apple, Nvidia, AMD, etc.

Wondering if anyone could speak on the differences between these two classes. Is there a lot of overlap? I was thinking of concurrently enrolling in 152 in the spring (will cost a lot of money) while taking 151 this coming fall. Do you guys think it is worth it? I really want to work for a company like nvidia down the road!
history.subject: 151 vs 152?
